posts.name: Ample Hills Creamery
posts.note: Ample Hills Creamery offers creative small-batch ice cream made with local ingredients. They use hormone free milk and cream from grass fed cows and organic cane sugar. If you like salted caramel ice cream, you need to try their Salted Crack Caramel, and their Dark Chocolate isn't bad either.

posts.name: Big Gay Ice Cream Shop
posts.note: With a playful attitude, Big Gay Ice Cream spins a new take on old-school soft-serve by creating fun and unique ice creams, toppings, and frozen treats that appeal to a diverse mix of clientele. The item to get is the 'Salty Pimp' which is vanilla soft serve ice cream in a cone injected with caramel, sprinkled with sea salt and then dipped in chocolate to form a hard outer coating.

posts.name: burger joint
posts.note: burger joint is a no-frills, cash-only burger counter hidden inside an upscale hotel. The best burger in New York City, hidden behind the curtain in the atrium lobby of Le Parker Meridien Hotel. It's a great little burger joint in the middle of an expensive hotel in New York City. You should order their cheese burger with lettuce, tomato, and mustard along with an order of fries and your beverage of choice.
posts.cptn: Cheese burger with lettece, tomatoe, and mustard along with an order of fries at the Burger Joint in the Le Parker Meridian Hotel New York City

posts.name: Cafe Orlin
posts.note: Cafe Orlin is a longtime cafe serving American and Middle Eastern food, best enjoyed on the street side patio and have a great weekend brunch. When I was there, I ordered an egg white omelette with multi-grain toast and herb infused home fries as a special.

posts.name: Chelsea Market
posts.note: Chelsea Market is a food hall, shopping mall, office building and television production facility located in the Chelsea neighborhood of the borough of Manhattan, in New York City.

posts.name: Cocoron
posts.note: Cocoron is a broth-based soba and sake highlight the menu of this small, unpretentious Japanese noodle shop.

posts.name: Crif Dogs
posts.note: Crif Dogs serves hot dogs with creative toppings and late-night hours make this spot a natural for post-bar munchies. You need to pick two hot dogs that catch your eye and order them with a side of French fries. If you can manage it attempt to get into PDT (Please Don't Tell) for a drink by going to use the telephone booth. There is a no standing rule, so they only allow enough people in to fill all the seats.

posts.name: Doughnut Plant
posts.note: Making doughnuts by hand with the highest quality all natural ingredients since 1994. They have a thing called donut seeds which are larger than donut holes but smaller than a regular donut. I ordered a bunch of different ones which were the rose water, Crème brûlée, peanut butter filled, orange glaze, some kind of chcoclate, and one more along with a hot chocolate for close to $20.

posts.name: Ducks Eatery
posts.note: Ducks Eatery is a diverse, meat-centric menu and has creative cocktails served in a rustic barn setting until late. You need to order the goat neck over rice with dried cherries or order the chicken wings too.

posts.name: Eataly
posts.note: They love high-quality food and drink. They love the stories about it, the people who produce it, and the places it comes from. I ate at the fish restaurant within Eatly but could have eaten at anyone of the other places too. They also have a beer garden/bar on the top floor that I saw had upscale bar food when I stopped up to look around.

posts.name: Haandi
posts.note: Bare-bones cafeteria serving Indian and Pakistani eats that claim a loyal taxi-driver following. People recommend order the goat head.

posts.name: The Halal Guys
posts.note: Once you have had a taste, you will understand why New Yorkers and tourists alike have stood in the city’s longest food cart line (sometimes for hours) to get a hot, steaming platter of chicken or gyro over rice, covered in The Halal Guys famous, proprietary White Sauce. You can't go wrong with the chicken or the lamb over rice with their white sauce. I went with the lamb because I don't get a chance all the time to order lamb. There was enough food for two full meals.

posts.name: Ippudo Ramen
posts.note: Ippudo East Village is the first international Ippudo to introduce the World to authentic Hakata tonkotsu pork soup. The best way to go is with two people and be willing to sit at the bar and watch the staff prepare the food in the process. If you go with two people you should order the pork belly steamed buns and their sticky sweat and hot pork ribs along with whatever Ramen suits your fancy.

posts.name: Ivan Ramen Slurp Shop
posts.note: Besides ramen, this noodle counter in Gotham West Market serves rice bowls and sides. I had the best bowl of Ramen I have ever had in my life the first time I was here. I got their classic Ramen with pork belly and a soft boiled egg.

posts.name: J.G. Melon
posts.note: They've been around since 1972 is a mark of quality in the New York restaurant market, which is extremely competitive.

posts.name: John's on 12th Street
posts.note: John's on 12th Street has classic red-sauce specialties, and vegan versions are served at this vintage-1908 Italian eatery. You need to order the meatballs in some fashion or other.

posts.name: Katz’s Delicatessen
posts.note: No-frills deli with theatrically cranky service serving mile-high sandwiches since 1888.

posts.name: Kunjip
posts.note: Bustling, 24/7 staple doling out seafood pancakes, bibimbop and other Korean items in a basic setting. Open 24 hours a day.

posts.name: Levain Bakery
posts.note: Cozy neighborhood bakery where locals are greeted by name. A steady stream of loyal regulars stand side by side with tourists, eager to sample the legendary baked goods.

posts.name: The Meatball Shop
posts.note: Fast casual service restaurant specializing in meatballs with 6 locations in New York City. I couldn't decide what to get and had planned to go somewhere else for a second dinner so I got thier three slider sampler which was the classic beef with tomato sauce, the spicy pork with whatever sauce they recommended, along with another slider that was on special which I think was lamb.

posts.name: Miss KOREA MEE
posts.note: Chic, zen-like Koreatown restaurant for barbecue, bulgogi and hot pots. Open 24 hours a day.

posts.name: New Wonjo
posts.note: Always-open Korean BBQ mainstay distinguishing itself with charcoal-fueled grills. Open 24 hours a day. My order was the Ox tail and ox blood soup along with and order of spicy pork and a bunch of other veggie condiments and steamed eggs
posts.cptn: Ox tail and ox blood soup along with spicy pork and a bunch of other veggie condiments and steamed eggs at New Wonjo in New York City

posts.name: Russ & Daughters
posts.note: Specializes in caviar, smoked fish, herring, bagels and elegant food gifts. Also offers catering services.

posts.name: Sake Bar Hagi
posts.note: Vibrant, open-late downstairs den offering a large menu of Japanese bites plus beer and sake.

posts.name: Salt and Pepper
posts.note: Casual eatery displaying ample hot American, Spanish, Indian and Pakistani dishes. I have found the Indian and Pakistani food to be the best such as the curry lamb or goat with chickpeas over rice.
posts.cptn: Goat or lamb curry and chickpeas over rice at Salt and Pepper which is located at 139 W 33rd St.

posts.name: Sister Midnight
posts.note: Late-night spot features a tiny bar and a bustling kitchen that turns out comforting dishes. One of which is their the cheeseburger, which is made from the restaurant’s own blend of short-rib, chuck and brisket. The 6-ounce patty is seared on the flat-top, then blanketed in tangy American cheese and nestled on a toasted potato bun slicked with tomato and mayo. Lettuce, tomato and onions complete the creation. And for those diners who prefer to forgo meat, the veggie burgers are truly delectable is and is described as a deep-fried, beet-centric dish as 'the perfect veggie burger.'

posts.name: Sobakoh
posts.note: Chefs make soba noodles behind a display window at this refined Japanese eatery.

posts.name: Spicy Village
posts.note: Chinese cafe serving Henan fare (hand-pulled noodles, pork pancakes & spicy chicken) in simple digs. The big dish is the chicken.

posts.name: Tori Shin
posts.note: Sophisticated Japanese eatery offering charcoal-grilled skewers and sake, plus a chef's-choice option. They are recommended by Izakaya Seki in DC.

posts.name: Torrisi Italian Specialties
posts.note: A seasonal, prix fixe-only Italian-American menu packs patrons into a cozy, exposed brick setting.

posts.name: Village Yokocho
posts.note: Chill second-floor eatery serving home-style Japanese fare in an evocative space. Friends say it's awesome yakitori (skewered meat).

posts.name: Yakitori Oh Taisho
posts.note: Late-night hours and yakitori (meat on a skewer) keep this East Village Japanese joint bustling.

posts.name: Yakitori Totto
posts.note: Upstairs Japanese yakitori spot transporting diners to Tokyo via grilled skewers & a bustling scene.

posts.name: Zabars
posts.note: Iconic store known for smoked fish, plus a huge variety of gourmet goods, prepared foods and cookware.

posts.name: Zaragoza Mexican Deli & Grocery
posts.note: Pint-sized market with basic Mexican staples & a counter serving classic take-out eats like tacos. Order whatever is on special.

posts.name: Zucker's Bagels and Smoked Fish
posts.note: Bagels (plus a wide selection of toppings), smoked fish, sandwiches & more in a bustling space.
